newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan seen tendering for soybeans, wheat - trade.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan seen tendering for soybeans, wheat - trade.

text.p: Taiwan is expected to tender for 54,000 tonnes of soybeans and for 68,000 tonnes of wheat over the next two weeks, traders said on Monday.
The Kaohsiung division of Taiwan's Breakfast Soybean Procurement Association is considering placing a tender for a 54,000-tonne shipment of soybeans for June delivery, they said.
The sharp fall in U.S. soybean futures prices on Friday may prompt the group to delay the tender to next week to see if prices will ease further.
The May contract on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) closed 24-3/4 U.S. cents down on Friday at $8.30-1/2 a bushel due to indications firm prices had sharply curtailed demand, U.S. traders said.
"Kaohsiung's soybean buyers were ready to enter the market this week, but now they will have to wait for the futures prices to hit bottom," an oilseeds trader in Taiwan said.
Taiwanese buyers were also expected to tender on Tuesday for two 34,000-tonne U.S. wheat shipments for late April to early June delivery, dealers said.

There were no corn tenders seen taking place this week as most buyers are still working on reducing inventories after an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease crippled the country's major pork export trade.
Taiwanese grain importers said they expected corn imports to slide by about 1.2 million tonnes, or 19 percent of the island's imports of 6.5 million tonnes a year.
Soybean imports may also fall by about 10 percent as the ban on pork exports slashes feed demand for soymeal.
Freight rates were seen at about US$14.00 a tonne from the Pacific Northwest and were quoted at $24.00-$24.50 a tonne from the Gulf of Mexico.
Taiwan Grain and Oilseeds Prices in Taiwanese dollars:
